Stuff7

CustomAPIs
Returns when the user created their account.

ENDPOINT

PARAMETERS

msg: Message to display.

{channel}'s account was created on {date}.

tz: Timezone to use for the date.

Unknown Region (UTC) Time

format: How to format the date.

Long

locale: Language in which to display the date.

English

EXAMPLE USAGE

!joined TIMEZONE

Response

USERNAME's account was created on Thursday, June 20, 2019 at 7:49:14 AM Coordinated Universal Time

Returns time since the account was created.

ENDPOINT

PARAMETERS

msg: Message to display. Syntax?

{channel}'s account is <{years} year{years(s)}>, <{months} month{months(s)}>, <{days} day{days(s)}>, <{hours} hour{hours(s)}>, <{minutes} minute{minutes(s)}>, <{seconds} second{seconds(s)}> and <{microseconds}ms> old.

EXAMPLE USAGE

!accountage USERNAME

Response

USERNAME's account is 7 months, 1 day, 17 hours, 4 minutes, 45 seconds and 864288μs old.

Returns how long a user has been following a channel.

ENDPOINT

PARAMETERS

msg: Message to display. Syntax?

{{follower}} has been following {channel} for <{years} year{years(s)}>, <{months} month{months(s)}>, <{days} day{days(s)}>, <{hours} hour{hours(s)}>, <{minutes} minute{minutes(s)}>, <{seconds} second{seconds(s)}> and <{microseconds}μs>.

EXAMPLE USAGE

!followage USERNAME

Response

USERNAME has been following CHANNEL for 7 months, 1 day, 17 hours, 10 minutes, 42 seconds and 962839μs.

REQUIRES AUTHENTICATION. Returns time since the stream started.

ENDPOINT

PARAMETERS

test: Simulate stream with the given date for testing purposes.

Select date

online: Message to display when online. Syntax?

{channel} has been live for <{days} day{days(s)}>, <{hours} hour{hours(s)}>, <{minutes} minute{minutes(s)}> and <{seconds} second{seconds(s)}>.

offline: Message to display when offline.

{channel} is offline.

EXAMPLE USAGE

!uptime

Response

CHANNEL has been live for 7 days, 14 hours, 47 minutes and 37 seconds and also 4564μs

You've probably noticed an special syntax in some of the input parameters. That's used to allow for a more dynamic way to format the time elapsed, here's a guide on how to use it:

Time variables tell you the time passed. Can be any of {years}, {months}, {days}, {hours}, {minutes}, {seconds} and {microseconds}

When dealing with plural words you can simply use the time variable as a function like this: {days(singularWord, pluralWord)}. In the example if the {days} variable is equal to 1 it will show the singularWord, otherwise it will show the pluralWord. The same applies for the other time variables.

Anything like <this> or [this] is called a block.

A block like this: <{days} passed> will only be shown if the variable used inside is greater than 0.

Meanwhile a block like this [{hours} live] will always be shown.

Anything between 2 blocks will only be shown if there's a visible block already placed.
